Articles.Content:
Hola, all. I'm having a bit of a problem with one of my rockets rolling when I try to do its gravity turns. It doesn't continually turn...only when I'm hitting D. I've read many, many threads about it, and I try to make sure I go no further than 45 degrees until my boosters burn out, but she continually rolls as I turn.

 

Rocket: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=667311729

 

Thanks.

Edited April 17, 2016 by Jesentra

"Rolling"? Not sure what you mean. Do you mean rotating on it's axis or that once you start to turn it keeps going and flips out?

Update: I've just built a close copy of your craft and it flies very well, no problems with the gravity turn. A few tips though...

Don't bother with RCS unless you are planning to dock, it just adds to mass, cost, drag, complication. Reaction wheels (in the capsule or added if needed) tend to do a better job and have unlimited use. Remove the monopropellant from the capsule to save payload mass. 

Don't over-strut. They are draggy and heavy. You could probably lose most if not all of the struts you have on your craft. 

For sub-orbital or low orbit you could very likely get away with no ablative in the heat shield, saving quite a bit of payload mass. 

Three winglets for attitude control can sometimes be sub-optimal. Four gives better control. 

Do you need the crew cabin? Is it for a contract? Otherwise ditch it to save mass. 

You can adjust your staging to run just the SRBs first as they give plenty of TWR alone. Then run the rocket engine after the SRBs have jettisoned. Will give more total dV to the craft.

Thanks for the reply. By "roll" I mean that it spins clockwise on its axis as I pitch to 90. 

 

I don't use the RCS for launch, only for docking operations. I actually had a few RCS tanks at the top there, but I took them off as part of my troubleshooting the rolling. 

I'll try removing the struts, thanks. I added then when I started noticing the roll, as some other threads attributed some rolling to wobbly parts.

I'll definitely try to add another fin, I had pondered it, I just wasn't sure I wanted to break up the three-point symmetry I had going. 

The ship was built for those "rescue" missions. I later had the thought to simply put a probe ontop of a normal command module, but I'm just fixated on trying to understand why the ship misbehaves. 

I've definitely tried to cut back the throttle on my engine during launch, but I've found the fins alone don't give enough steering without the rocket to put it into drift. 

I'll give some of these suggestions a go, thanks!

Could you upload a .craft file for us? My first thought was that the struts running diagonally from the SRBs to the center stack are causing torque, but it could also be the 3-way symmetry causing uneven drag.
